questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida in her third trimester is brought to the ER in an altered state of consciousness. Lab tests reveal elevated AST, ALT, and bilirubin, while a liver biopsy shows microvesicular fatty infiltration. Which enzyme deficiency is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The mother has acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP), which is associated with long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl CoA dehydrogenase (3-LCHAD) deficiency. This enzyme is involved in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids.

Women who develop AFLP have heterozygous mutations in the recessive gene for 3-LCHAD. The beta-oxidation capacity is reduced, but patients are asymptomatic outside pregnancy. AFLP develops when such women become pregnant with a fetus homozygous for the 3-LHCAD mutation. The fetus is unable to oxidize fatty acids, which then enter the maternal circulation. These fatty acids overwhelm the maternal oxidation capacity and cause acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. Biopsy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration. Fulminant liver failure can lead to hepatic encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is found to be hypotonic, with a high forehead, large anterior fontanelle, markedly separated cranial sutures, and hepatomegaly. Further investigations confirmed a diagnosis of the cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome. Which of the following biochemical findings would not be seen in this case?

choices.text: Elevated levels of very long chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
In cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome or Zellweger syndrome, there is a decreased level of plasmalogens.

Zellweger syndrome is caused by mutations in the peroxins (PEX) family of genes. As a result of this, there is a defective transport of the proteins to the peroxisomes. It severely impairs the functions of peroxisomes, resulting in defective beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA), defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

The child presents with

  • Dysmorphic facial features like wide anterior fontanelles markedly separated cranial sutures, epicanthal folds, broad nasal bridge, hypoplastic supraorbital ridges, etc.
  • Profound developmental delay, profound hypotonia with depressed deep tendon reflexes, neonatal seizures, and impaired hearing
  • Calcific stippling of the epiphyses
  • Renal cysts
  • Hepatomegaly

Biochemical findings will show:

  • Accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, phytanic acid, and pipecolic acids
  • Abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids
  • Marked reduction of plasmalogens
  • Elevated levels of plasma phytanic acid

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe, and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatrics department with a history of passing foul-smelling and greasy stools. A small intestine biopsy was taken and is shown below. The peripheral smear showed acanthocytes. Which of the following is unlikely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with steatorrhea, acanthocytosis on peripheral smear and histopathological slide showing lipid-laden enterocytes is most likely to be abetalipoproteinemia. Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disease. It is caused due to the mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP). MTTP is necessary to transfer lipids to nascent chylomicrons in the small intestine and to VLDL in the liver. In abetalipoproteinemia, there is an absence of chylomicrons, VLDL, LDL (apoB containing lipoproteins), and deficient levels of plasma cholesterol and triglycerides.

In abetalipoproteinemia, the usual presentation is fat malabsorption, diarrhea, and failure to thrive in early childhood. Vitamin E deficiency secondary to abetalipoproteinemia can lead to spinocerebellar degeneration. It manifests as loss of deep tendon reflexes, progressive ataxia, and lower limb spasticity by adulthood.

Intestinal biopsy shows lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium due to triglyceride accumulation. Accumulated lipids disappear after infants stop taking feed. Early treatment with supplemental vitamins, especially vitamin E, may significantly slow the development of neurological sequelae.

Acanthocytes (spur cells) are spiculated red cells with a few projections of varying size and uneven surface distribution. The image below shows acanthocytes in the peripheral smear.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with the history of polyuria and polydipsia was diagnosed to be suffering from type 1 DM. What will be the effect of this condition on the free fatty acid(FFA) level in this boy?

choices.text: Decreased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio
Increased FFA level due to Low glucagon: insulin ratio
Increased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio
Decreased FFA level due to low glucagon: insulin ratio

questions.solution:
In type I diabetes mellitus, there is an Increased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state and hence glucagon: insulin ratio will be high. The level of FFA, in turn, is controlled by glucagon:insulin ratio. Glucagon increases the FFA level and insulin has the opposite effect.

Note: Low insulin state also causes increased fatty acid oxidation leading to increased ketone body production and ketosis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought with hypotonia and loss of motor milestones. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly and macular cherry-red spot are noted. Foam cells are seen on bone marrow biopsy. Which is the most likely deficient enzyme in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of progressive neurodegeneration (loss of motor milestones, hypotonia) along with hepatosplenomegaly, macular cherry-red spot, and foam cells on bone marrow biopsy point to a diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease. The enzyme deficient in this disease is sphingomyelinase.

Niemann-Pick disease is disorder of infancy which is almost always fatal by 2-3 years of age. Although the affected infants are normal at birth, they soon present with failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, and rapid psychomotor retardation. Over time, there is severe loss of motor function and deterioration of intellect and death occurs by 3 years of age.

Niemann-Pick disease occurs due to the deficient activity of acid sphingomyelinase enzyme. There is extensive accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. Lipid laden foam cells are observed in bone marrow and lymph nodes. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the sphingomyelinase levels in the peripheral leucocytes. 

The management of Niemann-Pick disease is mostly supportive, such as physical therapy and a feeding tube for nutrition. Olipudase alfa has been recently approved for non-CNS manifestations of Niemann-Pick disease. 

Other options:

Option B: Hexoseaminidase A deficiency is seen in Tay-Sachs disease. While it also presents with progressive neurodegeneration and macular cherry-red spot, there is no organomegaly and lysosomes with onion skin are seen. 

Option C: Glucocerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher disease. The patients present with hematological abnormalities, organomegaly, and skeletal manifestations in the form of bone pain and pathological fractures. Bone marrow examination shows macrophages with characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance.

Option D: Galactocerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Krabbe disease. Both peripheral and central myelin is affected in this disease. The patients present with spasticity and intellectual impairment (destruction of central myelin) and peripheral neuropathy and absent deep tendon reflexes (destruction of peripheral myelin). Optic atrophy may also be seen.

questions.text: A man presents with blistering shortly after consuming alcohol at a party. He notes that this has occurred several times in the past. The lesions are shown below. What is the most likely enzyme affected in his conditon?
questions.solution:
The image given above is of porphyria cutanea tarda: erosions, blisters, pigmentary changes, and scarring. Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the commonest porphyria, as is likely in the case of blistering following alcohol consumption. It results from the deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD). This causes an accumulation of uroporphyrin and other highly carboxylated porphyrins. It is usually acquired (75%, sporadic) and is often associated with liver disease. It does not cause acute attacks. 

Patients notice increased fragility on light‐exposed skin, particularly the backs of the hands and forearms, with minor trauma shearing the skin away to leave sharply marginated erosions that crust and resolve over few weeks leaving atrophic scars, milia, and often mottled hyper‐ or hypopigmentation. Hypertrichosis on the upper face and forehead is common

Pink or coral-red fluorescence of urine is seen under Wood's light.

The classification of porphyrias based on their enzyme deficiencies is as shown below:

Option A: ALA dehydratase: ALA dehydratase deficiency

Option B: Uroporphyrinogen I synthase: Acute intermittent porphyria

Option D: Ferrochelatase: Erythropoietic Protoporphyria

  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text:
A 7-day-old term neonate presents with jaundice and on blood investigations, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen. The baby is otherwise healthy and exclusively breastfed. A diagnosis of breast milk jaundice is suspected. What is the pathogenesis of the condition?

MRP 2 - Multiple drug-resistant protein 2
questions.solution:
The pathogenesis of breast milk jaundice is increased ß-glucuronidase.

Breast milk jaundice is a type of neonatal jaundice that occurs in neonates due to breast milk feeding. It usually happens within the first week of life due to the abnormal accumulation of unconjugated bilirubin, leading to jaundice. The pathology of breast milk jaundice is attributed to the contents of breast milk whereas in breastfeeding jaundice there is inadequate breastfeeding.      

Breast milk contains inhibitors of UDP-glucuronyl transferase that prevents hepatic conjugation of unconjugated bilirubin. Another constituent of breast milk is ß-glucuronidase which is an enzyme that deconjugates bilirubin in the intestinal brush border, leading to increased serum reabsorption instead of excretion of bilirubin. Thus increases enterohepatic recirculation of unconjugated bilirubin. 

Infant factors contributing to breast milk jaundice include decreased gut flora that converts conjugated bilirubin into stercobilinogen and excreted in stools. As well as increased gut permeability in infants promotes the enterohepatic recirculation of bilirubin. 

Breast milk jaundice usually is self-limiting in the 2nd to 3rd week of life. Other causes should be ruled out in infants with severe or persistent jaundice. Rarely due to persistent elevated bilirubin levels, they may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24-48 hr and/or treatment with phototherapy without cessation of breastfeeding. 

Other options:

Option A: Breastfeeding jaundice occurs due to inadequate breastfeeding which typically reaches its peak between the third and fifth day after birth and is often accompanied by excessive weight loss. They also show increased unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Option B: Dubin Johnson syndrome shows multi-drug-resistant protein 2(MRP- 2) mutation. It is an autosomal recessive hyperbilirubinemia syndrome characterised by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and black-pigmented liver on biopsy due to an epinephrine metabolite. 

Option C: Crigler-Najjar syndrome type-I is due to the absence of UDP-glucoronyl transferase enzyme. It is an autosomal recessive hyperbilirubinemia syndrome characterized by severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and usually presents with kernicterus. It is usually fatal in the neonatal period.

questions.text: A father reports to a pediatrician with his daughter saying that she has episodes of lethargy, irritability, and vomiting right after she drinks fruit juice. Investigations show a deficiency of aldolase B enzyme. Which of the following need not be restricted in the patient's diet?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with symptoms occurring after ingesting fruit juices (containing fructose) and the absence of aldolase B enzyme point to a diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance. While fructose, sucrose, and sorbitol should be restricted in this patient, there is no rationale for restricting galactose.

Fructose 1-phosphate aldolase/aldolase B hydrolyzes fructose-1-phosphate into dihydroxyacetone phosphate and glyceraldehyde. Aldolase B is present in liver, kidneys, and small intestine. Note that while fructose 1-phosphate can be broken down only by aldolase B, fructose 1,6-bisphosphate hydrolysis (during glycolysis) can be undertaken by both aldolase A and aldolase B.

Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive condition due to aldolase B deficiency. Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). It usually presents during infancy when sugar-containing feeds are introduced, but some patients (who are less sensitive) can present at older ages as well. Clinical features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. Hereditary fructose intolerance can lead to hypoglycemia despite adequate glycogen reserves because fructose 1-phosphate is an inhibitor of liver glycogen phosphorylase.

Benedict's test is positive as fructose is present in the urine and it is a reducing sugar. Reduced levels of aldolase B activity in the liver and demonstration of pathogenic variants in ALDOB gene on molecular genetic testing give a definitive diagnosis. Treatment involves complete cessation of fructose, sucrose (glucose + fructose), and sorbitol (metabolized to fructose) from the diet.

questions.text: A young non-smoker with chronic cough and wheezing was diagnosed with α1 antitrypsin deficiency. The following image shows the normal electrophoresis of serum proteins. Which of the following bands (A, B, C, D) becomes thin in this patient?
questions.solution:
In α1 antitrypsin deficiency, the band that is marked as B, representing α1 globulin, becomes thin.

Serum protein electrophoresis is a method of separation and identification of proteins based on their net charge, size, and shape. The largest peak that lies closest to the positive electrode (left corner) is that of albumin since it is present in the largest proportion in plasma. Globulins make up a much smaller fraction of the total serum protein and are represented by smaller peaks to the right. Five globulin categories are represented: alpha-1, alpha-2, beta-1, beta-2, and gamma, with the gamma fraction being closest to the negative electrode (right corner).

Certain common diseases and their electrophoretic pattern:

Condition  Electrophoretic pattern
Chronic infections Smooth increase in gamma globulins
Multiple myeloma Gamma globulin part is increased as a single narrow peak (M BAND)
Malnutrition, cachexia, liver cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, severe burns Albumin is reduced
α1 antitrypsin deficiency α1 band is thin and even lost sometimes

The following image shows the bands with their corresponding proteins in normal serum electrophoresis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy comes to your OPD with pain in his right loin. The pain is colicky and radiates to his right testis. The patient has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Urine analysis shows crystals as in the image. What is a likely finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has cystine crystals in urine as depicted in the image implicating a diagnosis of cystinuria, in which urinary excretion of lysine is a likely finding.

Cystinuria is the most common inherited aminoaciduria. In this condition, a defective amino acid transporter in the proximal tube results in the urinary excretion of cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine (COLA). 

Cystine is urine insoluble, while the rest of the amino acids are urine soluble; thus, only cystine causes renal calculi(6-8% of total prevalence in childhood). Apart from cystine stones in the urinary tract, cystinuria is a benign condition not associated with any gastrointestinal or nutritional deficiency because of compensation by alternative transporters.

Homocystinuria, ornithinemia, and hyperammonemia are not found in cystinuria. 

Management is ample hydration, urine alkalinization, and cystine-binding thiol drugs to increase the solubility of cystine.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a rash on sun-exposed areas of the body and a history of ataxia and diarrhea. His urine shows the presence of only neutral amino acids. Which of the following tests is positive in this condition?
questions.solution:
A patient with manifestations of pellagra (rash in sun-exposed areas, ataxia, and psychiatric manifestations) along with the presence of neutral amino-aciduria points to the diagnosis of Hartnup disorder. The Obermeyer test is positive in this condition.

The Obermeyer test detects the urinary excretion of indole compounds. Indole derivates such as indican are found in large amounts in patients due to bacterial breakdown of unabsorbed tryptophan in the intestines. 

Hartnup disorder is an autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in the transporter for neutral amino acids like tryptophan. Decreased intestinal absorption of tryptophan in conjunction with its increased renal loss leads to its reduced bioavailability. This hampers niacin synthesis, and Hartnup disorder can thus present with manifestations of niacin deficiency (pellagra) like diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia.

The major clinical manifestation is cutaneous photosensitivity. The skin becomes erythematous after sun exposure and might develop a pellagra-like rash and eczema over time. Some patients might have intermittent ataxia manifested as unsteady, wide-based gait. Cognitive development is usually normal, but there may be episodic psychiatric manifestations such as irritability, emotional instability, and depression. 

The diagnosis of Hartnup disorder is established by typical clinical history and the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine. Urinary excretion of other amino acids remains normal, which differentiates it from causes of generalized aminoaciduria like Fanconi syndrome. Treatment with nicotinamide and a high-protein diet gives a good response in symptomatic patients.

Other options:

Option B: Benedict's test detects the excretion of reducing substances in the urine. About 0.5 ml of urine is boiled with 5 ml of Benedict's reagent for 2 minutes. The formation of a precipitate is observed on cooling. The test is semi-quantitative and the color of the precipitate roughly parallels the concentration of reducing sugar.

Option C: Guthrie bacterial inhibition test is a screening test for phenylketonuria. This test uses a phenylalanine requiring strain of Bacillus subtilis.

Option D: Seliwanoff's test will distinguish glucose and fructose. The reagent is resorcinol in HCl. 3 ml of the reagent and 0.5 ml of urine are heated for 30 seconds up to a boiling point. A red color indicates the presence of fructose.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient comes with multiple musculoskeletal complaints. Urine examination revealed blackish discoloration of urine on standing. Which of the following is not consistent with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Calcification of the intervertebral discs is seen on imaging.
It is a disorder of tryptophan metabolism.
Bluish-black pigmentation of the connective tissue is seen.
It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of alkaptonuria, which is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism. Hence, Option B is not consistent with the diagnosis. 

Alkaptonuria develops due to a defect in homogentisate oxidase, an enzyme that oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. A defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine. 

Hartnup disease is due to impaired intestinal and renal transport of tryptophan. The availability of tryptophan for the synthesis of niacin is reduced, which leads to pellagra-like manifestations.

Alkaptonuria is characterized by homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, and arthropathy (joint pain).

Homogentisic aciduria is the black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 

Arthritis generally begins in the third decade. Arthritis often begins in the spine and resembles ankylosing spondylitis in its large-joint distribution. Radiographs of the spine showing flattened and calcified intervertebral discs (Option A) are pathognomonic.

Ochronosis is bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue (Option B) that generally occurs after the third decade of life. It occurs due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and its oxidation products like benzoquinone acetic acid in connective tissue.

Alkaptonuria is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner (Option D).

Diagnosis: Blackish discoloration of urine on standing is diagnostic of alkaptonuria (shown below). The ferric chloride test will be positive.

The images below show pigmentation of the skin and an x-ray of the spine that shows calcification of intervertebral discs.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has a history of biting his fingers and lips. He has been diagnosed with hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase deficiency. What is an unlikely feature to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has Lesch Nyhan syndrome. Purine overproduction causes this syndrome; thus, decreased purine synthesis is unlikely to be seen in this patient.  

Lesh Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked disorder of purine metabolism that results from the deficiency of HGPRT enzyme (hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase). It is characterized by self-mutilation of fingers/mouth and dystonic movements. Other features include hyperuricemia, intellectual disability, and developmental delay (option c).

HGPRT enzyme is present in every cell but it is maximally present in basal ganglia, thus its deficiency affects basal ganglia by a reduction in its volume with loss of nigrostriatal terminals. This effect on the extrapyramidal system manifests as dystonic movements (option b). 

Investigations reveal elevated serum uric acid, urine uric acid: creatinine ratio, and HGPRT enzyme deficiency (option a).

The treatment mainstay is the prevention of renal failure by treating hyperuricemia with allopurinol/febuxostat and purine purine-restricted diet.

questions.text: A young girl is brought with a deformity of the upper limbs. She has a history of multiple fractures and her father has a similar history since his childhood. The image of the patient's eye and the radiographs of the upper limb are shown below. Which of the following is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing the blue sclera and bowing of the upper limbs are suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). It occurs due to the defect in the formation of type 1 collagen.

Osteogenesis imperfecta, also called brittle bone disease, is an autosomal dominant disorder. There are 8 types of osteogenesis imperfecta. It occurs most commonly due to mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes. These mutations lead to the replacement of glycine amino acid with another amino acid resulting in an abnormal triple helix of collagen. This results in the abnormal formation of type 1 collagen.

Since type 1 collagen is mainly present in the bone, ligament, dentin, and sclera, patients will present with repeated fractures, deformities of bone, blue sclera, and dental abnormalities.

The image given below shows different metabolic disorders of the bone.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male comes to casualty with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The onset of complaints is acute and the pain radiates to the back. You collect blood for lab investigations, however, the EDTA tube appears as shown in the image below after a few hours. Further investigations reveal liposomal lipase deficiency. What is the likely diagnosis of the condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has features of acute pancreatitis with blood showing a supernatant creamy layer after a few hours of collection and liposomal lipase enzyme deficiency. This points towards a diagnosis of hyperchylomicronemia syndrome (type 1 familial hyperlipoproteinemia).

Familial chylomicronemia is an autosomal recessive disorder with liposomal lipase deficiency. Liposomal lipase enzyme is required for hydrolysis of triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDL. Apo C II is the cofactor required for this enzyme. Deficient liposomal lipase in familial hyperchylomicronemia leads to elevated triglycerides, mostly in chylomicrons(= chylomicronemia), and elevated VLDL. When the blood is drawn, it is turbid, and with time, the chylomicrons with triglycerides rise to the top, forming a creamy supernatant. Apo CII mutation may present similarly but is a rarer cause. 

The patient has an elevated fasting triglyceride level (>500 mg/dL) and presents with acute pancreatitis, eruptive xanthomas (small yellow-white papules present in clusters on the extensor surface, back, and buttocks), and lipemia retinalis(opalescent retinal blood vessels).

Other options:-

Type II familial hyperlipoproteinemia caused by LDL receptor mutation is characterized by tendon xanthomas, raised triglycerides and LDL.

Type III hyperlipoproteinemia (familial dysbetalipoproteinemia) is caused by defective APOE, characterized by defective clearance of lipoprotein remnants in the liver. This increases serum chylomicron, VLDL, cholesterol, and triglycerides levels, causing xanthoma and vascular disease.

Abetalipoproteinemia is caused by an MTTP defect characterized by reduced serum cholesterol and triglycerides, negligible levels of chylomicron and VLDL, failure to thrive, and neurological manifestations due to a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins.

questions.text: An infant was brought to OPD with complaints of copious nasal discharge. On examination, there was a clouding of the cornea and hepatomegaly. The developmental assessment showed significant delay. An x-ray of the chest was taken and is given below. Which of the following enzyme is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of corneal clouding with hepatomegaly with developmental delay and the X-ray showing oar-shaped ribs is suggestive of Hurler's syndrome and the enzyme deficient in this condition is α-L-Iduronidase.

Hurler's syndrome is a severe type of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) - I. It is caused due to deficiency of α-L-iduronidase. This enzyme is required for the breakdown of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The deficiency of the enzyme leads to the accumulation of these mucopolysaccharides. 

Affected children usually present between 6-24 months of age. Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, large tongue, enlarged head circumference, joint stiffness, short stature, skeletal dysplasia, recurrent upper respiratory tract and ear infections, noisy breathing, and persistent copious nasal discharge. Children with Hurler's syndrome have impaired language function because of intellectual disability which occurs due to the accumulation of heparan sulfate and combined conductive and sensorineural hearing loss.

Skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex includes oar-shaped ribs(widening of anterior ribs), ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged diaphyses of the long bones, macrocephaly, and enlarged J-shaped sella.

The image below shows coarse facial features and the radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpal and phalanges.

Other options:  

Option A: Hunter syndrome is a type II MPS. It occurs due to the deficiency of iduronate 2-sulfatase. It shares the same features of type I MPS like coarse facial features, short stature, and dysostosis multiplex. However, there is no corneal clouding. It is the only MPS which X-linked recessive inheritance. So if a female baby is affected in the family, it is less likely to be Hunter syndrome. 

Option B: Sanfilippo syndrome A or MPS type III-A occurs due to the deficiency of heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase enzyme, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate. The affected children usually have delayed milestones and motor dysfunction.

Option C: Sanfilippo syndrome B or MPS type III-B occurs due to the deficiency of α-N-Acetylglucosaminidase enzyme, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate. The affected children usually have delayed milestones and motor dysfunction.

questions.text: A child presents with lesions as shown in the image below. He also complained of decreased vision at night. Which of the following dose of vitamin A prophylaxis given to children under the vitamin A distribution scheme in India could have prevented this condition?

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU  given yearly between the ages 1-6 years
1,00,000 IU  given yearly between the ages 1-6 years
1,00,000 IU  given 6-monthly between the ages 1-6 years
2,00,000 IU given 6-monthly between the ages 1-6 years

questions.solution:
The image above showing phrynoderma along with the history of decreased vision at night suggests a likely diagnosis of vitamin A deficiency. Under the vitamin-A distribution scheme in India, 200000 IU of vitamin A are given orally at 6-monthly intervals between the ages of 1 to 6 years.

Vitamin A deficiency can lead to mucocutaneous disease and result in various ocular complications, including blindness. The earliest signs of vitamin A deficiency are defective dark adaptation and night blindness (nyctalopia). Xerosis and scaling are commonly present in cutaneous findings.

Phrynoderma, which is characterized by the presence of keratotic follicular papules over anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms, is also seen.

Treatment is done by administering 50,000–2,00,000 IU of daily vitamin A supplementation until clinical signs and symptoms resolve and serum retinol levels normalize. 

The image below shows a Bitot's spot (due to vitamin A deficiency) seen as a foamy appearance on the surface of the conjunctiva:

questions.text: A scientist is trying to develop a drug for a genetic condition. He seeks a drug that could cause epigenetic alteration in the DNA and could prevent the disease or seemingly improve the condition. All the following would include epigenetic modifications, except _______.

choices.text: Altering the gene sequence of DNA
DNA methylation at CpG islands in promoter regions

questions.solution:
Epigenetic changes are heritable chemical changes in gene expression that are not caused by the alteration in the gene sequence. They alter gene expression without mutation.

The term “epigenetics” means “above genetics.” It refers to the regulatory mechanisms that do not change the underlying regulated DNA sequence, but rather change the expression patterns, or function, of the DNA. Epigenetic mechanisms play key roles in the establishment, maintenance, and reversibility of transcriptional states. It can cause both gene activation and inactivation.

Epigenetic modifications include

  1. DNA methylation- It is the covalent addition and subtraction of a methyl group to DNA. Methylation is typically done in cytosine preceding a guanine (CpG) dinucleotides. CpG islands are mainly present in the promoter region.
  2. Histone modifications such as acetylation, deacetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, etc. Acetylation of histone activates transcription, while deacetylation represses transcription.
  3. miRNA- micro RNA or miRNA are approximately 22 nucleotides long. They do not code. They bind to mRNA and inhibit its translation.

Clinical significance of epigenetic mechanisms:

  • Epigenetic modifications, such as histone acetylation and DNA methylation, are reversible, which makes them amenable for application in therapeutic intervention.
  • Histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors and DNA methylation inhibitors are being tested in the treatment of cancer. These agents inhibit transcriptional silencing and thus reverse the chromatin condensation in cancer cells.
  • These modifications include heritable changes such as X-inactivation and genomic imprinting, but they can also result from dynamic post-translational protein modifications in response to environmental influences such as diet, age, and drugs.

questions.text: An elderly patient on a vegetarian diet presenting with easy fatigability and pallor was investigated. Peripheral smear showed findings of macrocytic anemia. Investigations reveal elevated serum homocysteine levels and normal serum methylmalonic acid levels. What is the probable cause of anemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of megaloblastic anemia in a vegetarian with elevated homocysteine levels and normal serum methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels is due to folic acid deficiency.

Folic acid (vitamin B9) is a water-soluble vitamin, and its active form is tetrahydrofolate (THFA). It acts as a carrier of one-carbon groups. THFA is involved in the formation of many coenzymes in metabolic systems, particularly for purine and pyrimidine synthesis, nucleoprotein synthesis, and maintenance in erythropoiesis.

Folate deficiency results in megaloblastic anemia, homocysteinemia, and neural tube defects (spina bifida, Anencephaly) in the fetus.

Folic acid deficiency is associated with the following clinical and laboratory findings:

  • Raised MCV (normal range: 80–100 fL) - macrocytosis
  • Decrease in hemoglobin and hematocrit levels.
  • Normal MMA level
  • Elevated homocysteine levels.

where MCV is the mean corpuscular volume.

Patients with folate deficiency should be offered supplemental folic acid for the correction of the deficiency. Typically, oral folic acid (1 to 5 mg daily) suffices to treat folate deficiency 

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin B12 or cobalamin deficiency presents as anemia, fatigue, and pallor symptoms. Other presenting complaints may include peripheral neuropathy, glossitis, diarrhea, headaches, neuropsychiatric disturbances like dementia, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (SACD) leading to ataxia. A peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with raised serum methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels.

Option C: A patient with thiamine or vitamin B1 deficiency presents either dry Beriberi with predominantly neurological symptoms like neuropathy, muscle weakness, and wasting or wet Beriberi with predominant cardiac symptoms like cardiomegaly, tachycardia, high output congestive cardiac failure.

Option D: A patient with pyridoxine or vitamin B6 deficiency presents with symptoms of seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion, and normocytic anemia.

questions.text: A female patient underwent trucut biopsy of a breast lump. The following test was done on the specimen to confirm HER2 neu mutation. Identify the technique used.
questions.solution:
The technique shown in the image is fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH).

FISH is a technique where cells are stained with fluorescent stains. It uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions. FISH can be performed on prenatal samples, peripheral blood cells, touch preparations from cancer biopsies, and even fixed archival tissue sections. Uses include :

  • Numerical abnormalities of chromosomes e.g., aneuploidy.
  • Subtle microdeletions and rearrangements.
  • Complex translocations that are not demonstrable by routine karyotyping.
  • Gene amplification of HER2 in breast cancer or NMYC amplification in neuroblastomas.

Other options:

Option B: Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. It is used in prenatal diagnosis, investigation of repeat pregnancy loss, investigation of children and adults suspected of having a chromosomal disorder, and subtyping of lymphomas and leukemias for the purpose of exact diagnosis, giving a prognosis, and treatment.

The karyotyping of a normal human male is given below.

Option C: Immunohistochemistry (IHC) is a technique that uses the specific binding between an antibody and antigen to detect and localize specific antigens in cells and tissue. It is commonly used to assist in the classification of neoplasms, determination of a metastatic tumor’s site of origin, and detection of tiny foci of tumor cells. It is increasingly used to provide predictive and prognostic information in testing for HER2 amplification in breast cancer.

 

Option D : Microarray technique is used to detect multiple (thousands) genetic abnormalities on a single slide.

Microarray slide is given below. 

Related Pearl: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)

It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

  • Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.
  • Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions
  • Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.
